followUp.title: Progress Tracking
followUp.responsesSaved: Your responses have been successfully saved.

questions.painLevelChange: How would you rate your pain compared to the last assessment?
questions.painNatureChanged: Has the nature of your pain changed since the last assessment?
questions.painNatureDescription: How has the nature of your pain changed?
questions.painSpreading: Has your pain spread to new areas?
questions.newPainArea: To which new areas has the pain spread?
questions.exerciseEffectiveness: How effective are the exercises in relieving your pain?
questions.exerciseCompliance: How often do you follow the recommended exercise plan?
questions.painTriggers: Have the factors that trigger your pain changed?
questions.painReliefFactors: Have the factors that relieve your pain changed?
questions.overallImprovement: How do you rate the overall improvement of your condition?
questions.medicationUse: Are you using any pain medication?
questions.medicationEffectiveness: How effective is your pain medication?
questions.sleepQuality: How does pain affect the quality of your sleep?
questions.dailyActivities: How does pain affect your daily activities?
questions.workImpact: How does pain affect your work or studies?
questions.moodImpact: How does pain affect your mood?
questions.socialImpact: How does pain affect your social activities?
questions.treatmentSatisfaction: How satisfied are you with your treatment so far?
questions.overallFeel: How do you feel overall after completing the program?
questions.nerveSymptoms: Have your tingling or numbness symptoms changed?
questions.sensitivityChange: Has your sensitivity to touch, light or sounds changed?

descriptions.painLevelChange: Rate your current pain intensity on a scale of 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst imaginable pain).

general.title: Basic Pain Assessment
general.description: This questionnaire helps us understand your pain symptoms.

questions.painIntensity: What is your average pain intensity?
questions.painWithMovement: Does your pain increase with certain movements or activities?
questions.painIntensityIncrease: How intense does the pain become then?
questions.painOnsetTiming: How quickly does the pain start after those movements/activities?
questions.painSubsiding: How long does it take for the pain to subside afterwards?
questions.painDescription: How would you describe your pain?
questions.injuryStart: Did your pain start after an injury?
questions.activityStart: Did your pain start after a specific activity/movement?
questions.reflexes: Have you been told that you have markedly reduced or absent reflexes?
questions.sensitivity: Do you have increased sensitivity to light, sound or smells?
questions.variableImpact: Is the effect of the same movements/activities on pain unpredictable?

descriptions.injuryStart: We want to know if your pain began directly after a trauma such as a fall or impact.
descriptions.activityStart: Describe the specific activity that triggered your pain.
descriptions.reflexes: Loss of reflexes can reveal a lot about your condition.
descriptions.sensitivity: Answer yes only if this sensitivity appeared with your pain.
descriptions.variableImpact: Answer yes if you cannot predict when your pain will appear.

nociceptive.title: Nociceptive Pain Assessment
nociceptive.description: Helps us understand your tissue-related pain symptoms.

questions.restHelps: Does rest or avoiding painful movements help?
questions.worstTime: At what time of day is the pain usually worst?
questions.spineAbnormality: Have you noticed a pit in the spine or a protruding vertebra?
questions.lyingHelps: Does lying on your back relieve your symptoms?
questions.chestTightness: Do you feel any tightness in the chest?
questions.breathingPain: Do you feel pain or other symptoms when breathing in?

descriptions.restHelps: Does rest directly improve your pain?
descriptions.worstTime: Think about which part of the day is the worst for you and answer precisely.
descriptions.spineAbnormality: If unsure, ask a family member to check for a pit or protruding vertebra.
descriptions.lyingHelps: If you are unsure, try lying on your back and see if symptoms ease.
descriptions.chestTightness: We want to know if you have symptoms in the front of the chest.
descriptions.breathingPain: For example stabbing chest pain or stiffness when inhaling.

neuropathic.title: Neuropathic Pain Assessment
neuropathic.description: Helps us understand your nerve-related pain symptoms.

questions.coughingPain: Does coughing, sneezing or straining worsen your pain?
questions.abnormalSensations: Do you feel tingling, burning or electric-shock sensations?
questions.numbness: Do you feel numbness or heaviness in a specific area?
questions.muscleWeakness: Have you noticed muscle weakness affecting movement?
questions.reflexLoss: Have you lost reflexes in the affected limb?
questions.spineAbnormality: Have you noticed a pit in the spine or a protruding vertebra?
questions.lyingHelps: Does lying on your back relieve your symptoms?

descriptions.coughingPain: We want to know if coughing directly increases your symptoms.
descriptions.abnormalSensations: Answer yes if you can point to a specific path of sharp electric pain.
descriptions.numbness: Answer yes if you feel numbness or heaviness in the limb.
descriptions.muscleWeakness: Answer yes if weakness makes normal movement difficult.
descriptions.reflexLoss: Loss of reflexes can tell a lot about your condition.
descriptions.spineAbnormality: If unsure, ask a family member to check your spine.
descriptions.lyingHelps: Lie on your back for a couple of minutes and see if symptoms improve.

central.title: Central Sensitization Assessment
central.description: Helps us understand symptoms related to pain processing.

questions.painSpread: Is your pain spreading to areas that were originally unaffected?
questions.allodynia: Do normally non-painful stimuli cause pain?
questions.disproportionate: Does the pain feel disproportionate to your condition?
questions.sensorySensitivity: Along with pain, are you sensitive to light, noise or smells?
questions.cognitiveSymptoms: Along with pain, do you have fatigue or poor concentration?
